text: And so I came in swinging ready to go, and then about a month into my time there, I got a meeting on my calendar. Thursday 8:30 AM, was an hour and a half with half of the design team, so that was five people, and our HR partner. And so it was an extremely valuable learning experience and I took from that to then immediately shift how I was operating.
speaker: Katie Dill
context: Lenny asks Katie about a significant failure in her leadership career. Katie describes her first month as head of design at Airbnb, where she tried to make rapid changes to improve the team's low engagement scores and collaboration issues. However, five team members scheduled a formal meeting with HR to read from papers listing everything they thought she was doing wrong as a leader.
text_ko: 들어왔을 때는 바로 시작할 준비가 다 돼 있었어요. 그런데 거기서 한 달쯤 지났을 때 제 캘린더(calendar)에 회의가 잡혔어요. 목요일 오전 8시 30분에 1시간 반짜리였고 디자인팀(design team) 인원 절반인 다섯 명과 인사 파트너(HR partner)가 참석했어요. 정말 값진 배움이었고, 그걸 계기로 바로 제 업무 방식(일하는 방식)을 바꿨어요.
text_zh: 所以我一进去就干劲十足，准备大干一场。结果大概一个月后，我日程上突然多了个会议。周四早上8点半，要开一个半小时，参加的有设计团队一半的人，就是5个人，还有我们的HR合作伙伴。那次会议对我来说真的是个非常宝贵的学习机会，会后我马上就调整了自己的工作方式。
text_es: Entonces llegué con toda la actitud, listo para comermelo todo, y como al mes de estar ahí, me aparece una reunión en el calendario. Jueves 8:30 AM, hora y media con la mitad del equipo de diseño, o sea cinco personas, y nuestra compañera de Recursos Humanos. Y fue una experiencia súper valiosa de aprendizaje, así que de ahí mismo cambié completamente mi forma de operar.

text: And regardless of each individual thing, what was very clear was that the missing piece, the theme that was across all of that is that I hadn't earned their trust. So whether how right or how wrong what I was doing was is the key piece is that I wasn't bringing the team along with me.
speaker: Katie Dill
context: Katie explains her realization after receiving harsh feedback from her design team at Airbnb. The team had formally complained about her leadership approach through HR after just one month. Katie reflects on what she learned from this difficult experience about the importance of building trust as a foundation for effective leadership.
vocabulary_highlights: bringing the team along with me
text_ko: 그리고 각 사안을 떠나서 분명한 건, 모든 상황에 걸쳐 공통적으로 빠져 있던 부분은 제가 그들의 신뢰를 얻지 못했다는 거였어요. 제가 옳았든 틀렸든 핵심은 팀을 함께 데려가고 있지 못했다는 점이에요.
text_zh: 不管具体是什么事儿，有一点特别明显，就是我缺了最关键的一环——我没有赢得他们的信任。所以不管我做的事情对不对，核心问题是我没有把团队带起来，大家没有跟我一条心。
text_es: Y más allá de cada cosa en particular, lo que quedó clarísimo es que me faltaba una pieza clave, el hilo conductor de todo eso: no me había ganado su confianza. O sea, que tan acertado o equivocado que estuviera en lo que hacía, el punto clave es que no estaba llevando al equipo conmigo en el proceso.

text: I had some version of a panic attack, walked off stage, I was still mic'd up, cursed. I was laughing. I was like, 'Geez, are they laughing at me. Oh my God, this is...' But I can manage to turn it around, I walked back out, I'd kind of been disarmed internally in my head, and the rest of it went well.
speaker: Paul Adams
context: Lenny asks Paul about a memorable failure that scarred him for life. Paul describes freezing during a keynote speech at the world's biggest advertising festival in Cannes, representing Facebook. He had to walk off stage in front of thousands of people, and because his microphone was still on, the audience heard him curse. Despite this nightmare scenario, he managed to return and successfully complete his presentation.
text_ko: 공황발작(panic attack) 비슷한 게 왔어요. 무대에서 내려왔는데도 마이크가 붙어 있는 상태였고, 욕도 했어요. 웃어버렸고요. 속으로는 '사람들이 나 보고 웃는 건가? 세상에, 이게…'라고 생각했어요. 그런데 다행히 상황을 반전시킬 수 있었어요. 다시 무대로 나갔고, 머릿속의 긴장이 좀 풀린 기분이었고 나머지는 잘 진행됐어요.
text_zh: 我当时差点惊慌失措，直接走下台了，麦克风还开着呢，嘴里骂骂咧咧的。我还在那儿傻笑，心想"天哪，他们是在笑话我吗？我的天，这下完了..."不过我还是设法挽回了局面，重新走回台上，心里的那种紧张感反而消失了，后面就顺利多了。
text_es: Tuve algo así como un ataque de pánico, me bajé del escenario, todavía tenía el micrófono puesto, dije groserías. Me estaba riendo. Pensé, 'Dios mío, ¿se estarán burlando de mí? Ay no, esto está...' Pero logré darle la vuelta a la situación, regresé al escenario, como que ya me había relajado mentalmente, y el resto salió bien.

text: I think a lot of the motivation for those projects came from a place of fear. It didn't come from a place of let's make a great product for people, let's really understand the things people struggle with when communicating with family and friends. That's really, really try and create something wonderful. It came from a place of fear.
speaker: Paul Adams
context: Lenny asks Paul about his time working on failed social projects at Google like Google Buzz and Google+. Paul reflects on why these products failed, explaining that the motivation behind building them was fundamentally flawed. Instead of focusing on solving real user problems, the projects were driven by competitive fear of Facebook's success in social networking.
vocabulary_highlights: came from a place of fear
text_ko: 제 생각에는 그 프로젝트들에 대한 많은 동기가 두려움에서 온 것 같아요. 사람들을 위해 좋은 제품을 만들자거나, 사람들이 가족·친구와 소통하면서 겪는 어려움을 진짜로 이해해보자 하는 자리에서 나온 건 아니었어요. 진짜 멋진 걸 만들려고 정말 노력한 게 아니라, 결국 두려움에서 나온 거예요.
text_zh: 我觉得那些项目的动机很大程度上都是出于恐惧。不是说我们要为用户做个好产品，真正去理解大家在跟家人朋友沟通时遇到的痛点，然后真心实意地去创造一些很棒的东西。而是出于恐惧心理。
text_es: Creo que gran parte de la motivación detrás de esos proyectos venía del miedo. No venía de un lugar de "vamos a crear un producto increíble para la gente, vamos a entender de verdad con qué batallas la gente cuando se comunica con familia y amigos". De verdad intentar crear algo maravilloso. Venía del miedo.

text: The critique that is often leveled at Pets.com or at least at the time, was like, this is just a stupid business. They're shipping dog food around. You could never make that work, and that's just wrong. You absolutely can make it work. Probably can't make it work when 80% of the country on the internet is still on dial up. It's really, really early.
speaker: Tom Conrad
context: Lenny discusses how Tom took Pets.com from nothing to a public company to completely out of business in 19 months. Tom defends the business model, noting that Chewy later proved online pet retail could work with a $9 billion valuation. Tom explains that timing was crucial - Pets.com launched when internet adoption was still very limited, making the logistics and customer acquisition much more challenging than it would be later.
vocabulary_highlights: critique that is often leveled at
text_ko: 당시 사람들은 Pets.com에 대해 “그건 그냥 말도 안 되는 사업이야. 강아지 사료나 배송하고는 절대 안 될 거야”라고들 비판했어요. 그런데 그건 틀렸어요. 충분히 성공시킬 수 있어요. 다만 그때는 인터넷 이용자의 80%가 아직 다이얼업(dial-up)이었으니 아마 그때는 성공시키기 어려웠을 거예요. 정말, 정말 초기 단계였어요.
text_zh: 当时大家对Pets.com最常见的批评就是，这生意太蠢了，就是在网上卖狗粮嘛，怎么可能赚钱，但这种想法是错的。这种模式绝对能成功。只不过在那个年代可能确实做不起来，因为全国80%的人上网还在用拨号连接(dial up)，时机确实太早了。
text_es: La crítica que siempre le echaban a Pets.com en esa época era como que "este negocio es una estupidez, están mandando comida para perros por ahí, eso jamás va a funcionar", y eso está completamente equivocado. Sí se puede hacer que funcione, absolutamente. Lo que pasa es que probablemente no puedes hacerlo funcionar cuando el 80% del país todavía se conecta a internet con dial-up. Era demasiado temprano, la verdad.

text: For me, failure is not that you didn't drive revenue, failure is not learning. So it's really important that you learn when you fail. And so we celebrate failure as long as you're learning, and you can only learn if you've designed the right test and you failed conclusively, because otherwise I think many of us have been in situations where there's intuition that something might work and it doesn't work, and then you end up doing it over and over for years.
speaker: Sri Batchu
context: Lenny asks Sri about creating a culture where people aren't afraid to take risks, given that growth experiments typically have only a 30% success rate. Sri explains his philosophy that the real failure isn't when experiments don't drive revenue - it's when teams don't learn from their failed attempts. He emphasizes the importance of designing conclusive tests to avoid repeatedly trying the same ineffective approaches.
text_ko: 제게 실패는 매출(revenue)을 못 올린 게 아니라 배우지 못한 거예요. 그래서 실패했을 때 배우는 게 정말 중요해요. 배우고 있다면 실패를 오히려 축하해요. 다만 제대로 된 테스트(test)를 설계해서 명확하게 실패했을 때에만 진짜 배울 수 있어요. 그렇지 않으면 많은 분들이 ‘이게 통할 것 같다’는 직관(intuition)은 있는데 실제로는 안 되는데도 수년 동안 같은 걸 계속 반복하게 돼요.
text_zh: 对我来说，失败不是指你没做出业绩，真正的失败是你没有从中学到东西。所以失败了以后一定要有收获，这特别重要。只要你能从中学到东西，我们就鼓励试错，但前提是你得设计好测试方案，让失败来得明明白白，要不然很多时候我们凭感觉觉得某个方法可能行，结果不行，然后就一直重复同样的错误，搞好几年都没进展。
text_es: Para mí, el fracaso no es que no hayas generado ingresos, el fracaso es no aprender. Entonces es súper importante que aprendas cuando fallas. Por eso celebramos el fracaso siempre y cuando estés aprendiendo, y solo puedes aprender si diseñaste bien la prueba y fallaste de manera concluyente, porque si no, creo que muchos de nosotros hemos estado en situaciones donde hay una corazonada de que algo podría funcionar y no funciona, y entonces terminas haciéndolo una y otra vez durante años.

text: I think there wasn't really a clear path. I think there was [inaudible]. Exactly. And it was more just like if you understood, again, this is my point around unit economics, there are things where I think you have magical thinking around unit economics. You're like, 'Well, when we get to the scale of X, it's all going to work out. We can make these things happen.' I think you actually need to really make sure the unit economics work right at the beginning.
speaker: Jiaona Zhang (JZ)
context: Lenny asks JZ whether Airbnb Plus could have succeeded with better execution or if the business model was fundamentally flawed. Airbnb Plus was an attempt to create managed, inspected inventory to address trust issues, but it required significant operational investment. JZ explains that the project suffered from 'magical thinking' about unit economics - the belief that profitability would somehow emerge at scale without the fundamental economics working from the start.
text_ko: 솔직히 말하면 뚜렷한 길이 있던 건 아닌 것 같아요. 중간에 잘 안 들리는 부분도 있었고요. 맞아요. 제 요점은 유닛 이코노믹스(unit economics)에 관한 건데, 어떤 부분에서는 이걸 마치 마법처럼 생각하는 경향이 있어요. ‘우리가 어느 정도 규모(X)에 도달하면 다 해결될 거야, 이렇게 만들 수 있을 거야’라고요. 근데 저는 실제로 초반부터 유닛 이코노믹스가 제대로 맞는지 확실히 해야 한다고 생각해요.
text_zh: 我觉得当时确实没有一个很清晰的路径。对，就是这样。更多的是如果你理解了——这又回到我说的单位经济效益(unit economics)的问题，有些时候你对单位经济效益会有一种不切实际的想法。你会想："等我们达到X这个规模的时候，一切都会顺理成章，我们就能把这些事情搞定了。" 但我觉得你其实需要从一开始就确保单位经济效益是行得通的。
text_es: Creo que no había realmente un camino claro. Creo que había [inaudible]. Exacto. Y era más bien como si entendieras, otra vez, este es mi punto sobre la economía unitaria (unit economics), hay cosas donde creo que tienes un pensamiento mágico alrededor de la economía unitaria. Te dices, 'Bueno, cuando lleguemos a la escala de X, todo va a funcionar. Podemos hacer que estas cosas pasen.' Creo que realmente necesitas asegurarte de que la economía unitaria funcione desde el mero principio.

text: But between all of those highlights, there were so many B moments that get shoved under the rug because it's just easier for me and it's more impressive for others. But I really like to highlight those because I think that most of us have a lot of B moments every day, every week, every month, and every period of our lives.
speaker: Gina Gotthilf
context: Lenny asks Gina about her concept of having both an 'A side' and 'B side' to everyone's career - where the A side contains impressive achievements that people share publicly. Gina explains that people naturally focus on sharing their highlights (A side) while hiding their failures and struggles (B side), but she believes it's important to acknowledge these B moments because they're a normal part of everyone's professional journey.
text_ko: 하지만 그런 하이라이트들 사이사이에, 저한테는 더 편하고 다른 사람들에게는 더 인상적이니까 그냥 숨겨 버려지는 B 순간들(B moments)이 정말 많아요. 저는 오히려 그런 순간들을 더 부각시키는 걸 좋아해요. 대부분의 사람들이 매일, 매주, 매달, 그리고 인생의 여러 시기마다 이런 B 순간들을 많이 겪는다고 생각하거든요.
text_zh: 但是在这些高光时刻之间，其实有很多平平无奇的B级时刻，我们往往会把这些藏起来不说，因为对我来说这样更省事，对别人来说也显得我更厉害。但我特别想说说这些平凡时刻，因为我觉得咱们大部分人每天、每周、每月，人生的每个阶段，其实都有很多这样的B级时刻。
text_es: Pero entre todos esos momentos destacados, hubo muchísimos momentos B que uno tiende a barrer bajo la alfombra porque es más fácil para mí y queda mejor ante los demás. Pero me gusta mucho resaltar esos momentos porque creo que la mayoría de nosotros tenemos un montón de momentos B todos los días, todas las semanas, todos los meses, y en cada etapa de nuestras vidas.
